This has to be my most re-watched film in the last five years. Memories of Murder is an incredibly impressive second movie from the now internationally very well known Bong Joon-ho.The film is loosely based on the true case of the first serial killer in South Korea. Usually I find difficulty watching crime films or shows based on actual events, particularly if they show a great deal of the actual crimes. For example, I had to stop watching the recent Dahmer show. Something just felt icky about how intimately it displayed events.Memories of Murder focuses more on the characters, how the case shifts their motivations and attitudes towards their work, and the effects of mismanaged justice. These people are at times funny, spiritual, irresponsible, empathetic and cruel.We see the small moments in-between important plot beats for the case. Talking to their partners, dinners out at a cozy restaurant, fighting protestors as the fifth republic of Korea falls apart around them; a brilliant shot lingers on the final stages of a wild karaoke night.Speaking of visuals, the character ensemble framing is outstanding here. So many shots with the whole main cast in them is very refreshing.The mundane locations help the film stay grounded, and the way the camera controls the viewers' eyesight is masterful. The shots have a lot of info in them, but we are drawn to motion, or characters' eyesight.All of this is accompanied by a brilliantly melancholic score by Taro Iwashiro. The ending song I have listened to more times than I would care to admit.So back when I decided to go through Bong Joon-ho's filmography by release order, I did not expect his second film to be as excellent as it was. I especially didn't expect a development in the actual case to happen two days after I watched it (September 16th, 2019 was my first viewing). I will refrain from saying what exactly happened, but I do implore people to watch the film first, then research afterwards.This is a wonderful, atmospheric, funny, tragic, well-made film, and at the moment, one of my favourites of all-time.

reviews.review_title: Overrated, doesn't follow it's own rules
reviews.content: As some other reviewers have pointed out, a significant portion of this film is basically a comedy, including comedic stooges-esque slapstick juxtaposed with a murder-rape victim's corpse in near-proximity. It doesn't fit with the film, is arguably in poor taste, and at times was just downright silly.The comic detective versus the serious detective plays out well enough. But then they reverse roles in the climactic scene for apparently no reason. The serious cop was adamant about the reliability of documents, but then he suddenly says "I have no need for this document" when it didn't fit his narrative. But they had established him as someone who was attentive to the facts. Why did he suddenly become a completely psychotic emotional wreck in the climax? \(°_o)/. Supposedly seeing a victim he knew personally triggered him, but that was alien to his establishment as a level-headed character who would not have wanted to seek revenge on someone that documented DNA evidence cleared of guilt. There was no explanation or buildup as to why the comic and serious detectives switch personalities. Only the comedic guy was prone to manipulating the solving of a case for his own glory. Earlier in the film, the serious guy explicitly avoids such motives, and yet does a 180.Then, as others have pointed out, there were the inconsistencies in the murder profiles. At first it was single women wearing red in the rain. Then rain became optional. Then it even included a child. There was one scene where they interrogate a girl who wasn't killed, and she claimed it was because she didn't look at the guy's face. Was that accurate? \(°_o)/. All we know is he didn't kill her for some reason, which was another anomaly in the profile. By the end of the film, the killer was including mutilations and random objects in his killings that are never built out. There is never a coherent profile of the killer.Again, as others have pointed out, one of the key "clues" was a completely random deus ex machina where a side cop randomly noticed the same song on the radio exactly on the nights that 3 of the murders took place. This is never explained. One of the suspects admits to placing the song requests, but there is never any explanation of why that guy - who is later vindicated by DNA - made those song requests at those times. During an interrogation of that same suspect, the detective starts counting the number of peach pieces at the crime scene, and this clearly upsets the suspect, who starts screaming to shut up. So why would he be so emotional by that description of the crime scene? That suspect was cleared by DNA. Are we supposed to believe the DNA was wrong? If so, there was no indication given that it was. And if the DNA was accurate, there was no logical reason for an otherwise staid suspect to freak out suddenly at a detective counting peaches - other than to try to trick or confuse the viewer with random character behaviors, which is just lame writing.In the film's postscript that takes place in 2003, the comedic guy decides to visit the first crime scene which is in the middle of a gigantic empty field. He ducks down to look at where the body is and when he pops back up again, wouldn't you know there happens to be a young girl there by herself *in the middle of the gigantic empty field* who tells him she recently talked to a guy looking at the same spot and this guy looked "ordinary" and comedic guy ends the film breaking the 4th wall. This is supposed to be some profound end to a masterpiece? Another deus ex machina of encountering this girl - who also encountered the killer - who himself apparently visited that spot recently - in the middle of a cornfield twenty years later? Seriously? And he looks ordinary so the detective looks into the camera, cuz it could be anyone. That's not profound. That's what follows a film with no coherent puzzle to solve.The clues don't add up. The killer has no consistent MO. The detectives have inconsistent personalities. Nothing fits together nicely.From a cinematic and acting perspective, the film is solid. It doesn't follow the predictable "Disney" protagonist rise-fall-redemption arc, so that's a plus of any film anymore. None of that is enough to give this a favorable score.

reviews.review_title: A Little Overrated in My Opinion
reviews.content: I didn't dislike the film, there were lots of elements that I enjoyed but some that were a bit strange for me. For me the average rating of this film on here at 8.1/10 is ridiculously high, I even see a review on here calling this the best crime/detective film ever. I'm not sure if the author of that review either wants to be edgy or hasn't seen many detective films. In my opinion Se7en is the best detective film ever made.Back to this film. The tone shifts mid scene were really jarring. There would be wacky slapstick violence during dramatic scenes that didn't do it for me.For the most part the performances were quite good and the character arcs of the detectives felt deserved and justified. I thought the third act was a bit rushed but I liked the last scene, especially when I later found out that the film was based on true events giving a little more context to the final scene.As I said I liked this film and i'm not hating but if you've rated this 10/10 ask yourself. If this was based in a small town in Texas with an American Cast would this have an average rating higher than 6.7/10. Again i'm not hating as a lot of my favourite films are foreign but sometimes there's a bit of snobbery in the ratings of foreign films on here.
One of the best ever! Actors were top class. Story keeps you glued to the seat. Ending leaves you confused but that's the best it could get.

I had seen the parasite movie and was astonished by the story and making of it. But I was not aware that the same director had had directed this movie until I finished watching it.What a direction, fantastic. Marvelous acting, incredible cinematography, a great screen play.I don't know how this movie missed the Oscar win.

reviews.review_title: True story so don't expect cinematic stuff
reviews.content: The movie was well scripted and genuine to the audience. The story is all about investigating the rape and murders in a specific region. It depicts how police investigate, superficially and unprofessionally, in those rural regions. If someone is a Sherlock Holmes fan, then they will be utterly disappointed. If there is a Sherlock Holmes in reality and sees this movie, he would be plucking his hairs for the way police investigated the case. The movie just illuminate the pathetic investigation all through the story. But then again the story was real and you don't wonder why the serial rapist/killer is not caught at all. If there was a studious investigator in reality, he would have finished the case a long ago with his meticulous scientific inquiry. Nevertheless, I really recommend the movie for how the depict the reality of investigation and how they approach the criminals. I definitely recommend to those psychopathic serial killer movie lovers ;)

There's a quiet sense of hysteria present throughout Joon-ho Bong's Memories of Murder. Though on the surface the movie plays as a detective with many comedic elements, its true core consists mostly of deep despair and paranoia. It is a testament to the director's skill that these two sides are joined together so well without it resulting in a disjointed mess.Memories of Murder portrays a case of a serial rapist in a small town on the outskirts of the Korean countryside. Three detectives with very different methods of investigation are put together to search for the killer. It becomes quickly clear that this isn't a usual case and the complexity of the case puts the detectives way over their head. You get the sense that these are effective investigators in their own right, but they are way outmatched for the situation they are put up against.Part of the effectiveness of the film is that it actually conveys the overwhelming fear that slowly seeps into the persons facing the unknown evil. The horrific acts committed are all the more scary because they are happening in a town with seemingly nice people. Everyone in the town seems to know each other by name. This makes the killer seem like somewhat of an alien presence, a ghost hiding behind a human face. As the girl describes the presumed killer in the end, his appearance was that of just an "ordinary" guy. The most scary thing is that he isn't a hideous deformed creature driven to these disturbing acts, but that this person could ostensibly be hiding in each other person that you know, with no way to determine which one in particular.Because there seems to be no rhyme and reason to what is happening the movie makes for a very scary experience. I have to admit I am not an avid watched of foreign films, but at the same time I found this movie to be thrilling to watch. It is not a light experience (it will likely leave you drained at the end) but very worth seeing. Highly recommended.

reviews.review_title: Have no idea what I just watched
reviews.content: First time ever that I walked out of the movie theatre in 40 years. That says it all.Complete lack of credibility in the police work. It was comedial. Torturing suspects, planting evidence and no oversight anywhere.No way a high-profile case could stay with a bunch of complete jokers like this.It had no idea if it wanted to be funny or serious and the complete lack of tone totally ruined it for me.IMDB must have been hacked for this score.Unbelievable.

reviews.review_title: Wish we know the backstory more
reviews.content: I feel that if we had known more that this was an actual real story and some details, then the ending would have been less confusing. Like one slide at the beginning that would have said something.

Parasite might have gotten Bong Joon Ho his recognition in the US; but I think Memories of Murder shows his abilities that much better. Very interesting plot very traditional crime thriller mystery; but also almost who-done-it style. Excellent acting, great writing, beautiful cinematography. I think this film will eventually be recognized as a masterpiece and I hope american filmmakers pick up on how well a movie like this can be made.

reviews.review_title: A true 'underrated' masterpiece from Bong Joon Ho.
reviews.content:
1986 South Korea. Several rape and murder case reports are coming one at a time. One local detective, and an other from Seoul starts
the investigation , start gathering clues, evidences. Although their ways of investigation were different, at the end they came together. There's a lot of humour too, in the movie, amidst the seriousness. One thing I can tell you, since this is based on a true story, the ending you may know beforehand. But please don't miss the ultimate ending scene. That's why I loved the movie so much.

This film shocks you, relaxes you and then hits you hard in the chest. I cursed myself for discovering it so late. It now belongs to my forever collection. This is a film which doesn't merely executes a story, it lives it with compelling characters and the realism with which it has been made. Evergreen Kang-Ho Song is the ruler here with Kim Sang-kyung playing a equally essential role. The story doesn't play the happy-journey card anywhere, instead it asks some intriguing questions to the viewer. This film left a taste in me and I feel happy about it. Namaste to the creators of such incredible cinema.

reviews.review_title: I cant stop thinking bout the end
reviews.content: Excellence pure excellence by bong joon ho..a masterpiece in thriller film making.

The movie has everything you could ask for it has thrill, horror, good characters, cinematography, a piece of family life, sexual scenes, fighting/action, acting. And most importantly is was directed by bong joon ho.

reviews.review_title: A gem. Must watch for any crime/thriller aficionado.
reviews.content: I just finished the movie and I'm lost for words.Literally, I don't know what to think about the movie, and I guess that's the beauty of it.Some people will love the ending, some will hate it, but nobody can say that this movie is not unique in its own way.I cannot remember the last time I felt like this way once the credits started rolling.The music. The cinematography. The story.I loved it.

reviews.review_title: An amalgamation of Zodiac, Se7en and The Chaser.
reviews.content: Memories of Murder is an ingeniously devilish mix of Zodiac, The Chaser and Se7en. It takes the heavy police procedural route of Zodiac where it avoids the typical police Hollywood thriller chase conventions, the rainy atmosphere of Se7en to signify the movie's tone and the examination of the fallible nature of the Korean police from The Chaser.

reviews.review_title: A modern day masterpiece done by a modern day master
reviews.content: Korean cinema at the moment is at the pinnacle of both commercial and critical success. The country is blessed with the acting talents from the likes of Min-sik Choi, Kang Ho-Song and Byung-Hun Lee along with visionary directors such as Chan-Wook Park, Kim Jee-Won and Bong Joon-Ho. Just as "Oldboy" is arguably categorized as Park's masterpiece, "Memories of Murder" is the film which established Bong Joon-Ho as being a visionary on his own right.The film, as the title suggests, is based on a murder being investigated by two detectives; Park Doo-Man (Kang Ho Song) and Cho Yong-Koo (Ro-ha Kim). Due to the publicity that the killings are getting in their area, Seoul decides to send Detective Seo Tae-Yoon who will help the current detectives with their case. This film, however, is not your conventional detective drama. This is an exercise on "Who-Dunnit" films which even the master Alfred Hitchcock would be proud of. The heart of the story, unlike the films from it's genre, is not in in it's mystery, but in it's exploration of the protagonists and the motives and reasons which drove hem through the case. Throughout the film we will also explore into the nationalistic and social environments that these characters had to come through to stay focused on the task that mattered the most; solving this case.The film is a little more than 150 minutes in length and is engrossing for that whole period. This is hard to find in mystery films but it achieved this not only through the master story-telling of Bong Joon-Ho, but due to the absolute mesmerizing performances given by Kang Ho-Song, Sang-Kyung Kim and Roe-ha Kim. The three detectives complemented each other with sublime chemistry but the star of the show was Kang-Ho Song. Song is established as one of the most accomplished actors to come out of Korea and this film, along with J.S.A., helped him to establish a reputation which is as strong today as it was then. The film is the only time when the characters were not defined by the story or vice-versa, but they perfectly complemented each other due to the skill that both the film-maker and the actors had in both their trades. Bong Joon-Ho is not as stylish as Park Chan-Wook is or as outrageous in his art as Kim-Jee Won is, but his vision helped give birth to another kind of film-maker from Korea who focused on simplicity a lot more than his counterparts to bring forth a complicated vision. This film was one of the first ones to promote this vision and to this day it stands as a film which defines this extremely different visionary who emerged out of this small but culturally rich nation.

When i watched this movie i had great expectation because of high rating in IMDB but that wasn't so great. At beginning movie looks very unique, and after some time it feels like it is mean to be comedy but at last it feels like much serious and in finale whole points seems worthless.
This movie had great potential to be masterpiece but it lost its way. The good thing about the movie is it's feels like different movie until the end. The bad thing about the movie is it is trying to be movie like M1931 but without the solving case.
Thanks.

reviews.review_title: Genuinely blown away at the 10/10 reviews
reviews.content: Definitely not the worst crime drama I've ever seen but it was pretty close. I was excited when I saw it was the same Director as Parasite as I thought that film was true perfection in many ways... Whereas I found Memories of Murder nonsensical. I understand that solving violent crimes in Korea in the 80's was probably as much of a disaster as portrayed in the film, but certain scenes were reminiscent of Telenovela acting and it was difficult to keep my focus despite needing to read subtitles. The film is worth a watch for the story line alone, but the acting is what will keep me from watching it a second time.

I haven't watched so many Korean movies compare with other area's, but honestly I always like to have a try since Parasite won the Oscar in 2019. But I choose this Memories of Murder first instead of watching that one directly. Maybe some kinds of preparation I think. And now, I can't wait for watching the next coming Korean movies.This crime movie tells a simple story, officers finding the criminals. But the director has combined so many 1980s Korean countryside scenes within it, and makes everything vivid. The actors also made a perfect performance of a simple countryside policeman. There are no cool-handsome guy with clean suits, no exciting gunfire and car crash, and no beauties with sexy body line, like other main Shows did. There just have the cold rain, dangerous country road, and animal covered with man's skin.And of cause, justice didn't win.

reviews.review_title: INTRIGUING BUT YOU'LL GET NO CLOSURE
reviews.content:
THE GOOD:
A surely interesting watch with very interesting characters. Each have their own personalities and the actors really play well in their roles. We're convinced that they are who they are and not, well, acting. Something that Asian does best in my opinion.The plot is interesting, with enough new evidence scattered around the runtime to not bore us.THE BAD:
Not a must watch nor a masterpiece. The movie surely is interestingly shot, however nothing makes it groundbreaking in any way. The plot is thrilling but inconclusive. The chase is interesting but no cat & mouse play is at stake since we've never ever came close to the killer. In short, this is a good watch but certainly not a must see to expand your cinema knowledge.

reviews.review_title: A masterpiece in its own right!!
reviews.content:
This movie is all about the tribulations faced by the detectives once there is a serial killer on the prowl. The chaos that ensues and the fear psychosis which grips the community can only be assuaged once the killer is caught. And this can sometime lead to botched up investigations and over zealous attitude and brutal methods being adopted. The "Good Cop Bad Cop" routines, Confessions being forced all leading to it becoming a sham.
The way the story is built up and details of the murders.. the surroundings....the rain...the "Sad Letter" song... the method of brutal rapes and murders... all instill a sense of fear for the personality of the murderer. He does not use any sophisticated weapons.... rather the victim's possessions only to do his job but carefully selects them.
And our detectives hard pressed to find him go overboard many times but he just keeps giving them the slip... and even when they think they have him there aint enough evidence... the frustration and despondency even forces a do right cop to flip into a violent one.
For me the concluding scene is the best where Sang Kang Ho sits near the scene of first crime and contemplates what could have been...
Yes.. a few scenes could have been done away with but they are like invisible blips on the canvas...
Superb!!!

This is an extremely well crafted vintage style thriller - 80s. There are so many clues and so nicely directed and edited, you want to watch it again right away. Makes you think for a few days after you've seen it.With Kids - No!Watch again - Perhaps a couple of times. .

reviews.review_title: Be ready to be disturbed & disappointed
reviews.content: Not everyone would like this movie, not because it's not worth watching, but it doesn't end on a good note as every human nature wants.But it is what it is. And it is worth the time.It starts lightly, describing the characters, adding weight to the story, downfalls of characters giving you the chills, and a never ending emotion that grips your heart (You will know the emotion once you watch).Not too gore, but still it gets the better of you and makes you think ''Really''!!!

Actually I heard lot of things positive about this movie ,some people said is the best one in Asia
for my opinion I think Is a simple movie ,no way to stay in list top 250
I have an problem with the detectives in that city ,there is no professional in work ,I think there is a touch of comedy on moviethis is it
I totally do not understand this rating. This movie is just a disaster and a waste of time.

After watching OLDBOY and MEMORIES OF MURDER 
I understand that koreans dominating drama thriller crime movies. 
It was fantastic. For sure one of the best in history in its genre.
With a great acting performances and very very strong story to keep you without blinking an eye for couple of hours in front of the screen.

It is THE BEST crime thriller I have ever watched. It is a masterpiece even though being the second film for the director. Yes, this is a slow-paced movie but the slow-pacing is rather a plus point for this film. In my opinion, this is Bong's best work yet.

There is a lot of great movies talking about mystery murders and murderers, but in my opinion there is two movies are the top, one of them is Zodiac (2007) from the genius David Fincher. and the other one is Definitely this movie memories of murders from the genius South Korean Bong Jon-Ho.
the movie takes place in South Korea in 1987, about a mysterious murders happen in a small city by a serial killer, and we see two Detectives from the police while they collecting evidences trying to arrest him, so we go along with them in their journey to find out the truth.
in my view this movie is very unique and has a very special theme,
what I like about this movie is that the main character and his friend are not genius or heroes like the other movies, they are not very smart at all and they have no values and morals, they are trying to do anything for their best interest, they don't care about arresting the killer or solving the case in the right way, this was great in the movie.
the directing by Bong Joon Ho was a great, he had the right style for telling the story, specially with using the Long take shots in the right moments and the right places, this type of shots lit the actors show their abilities. the acting was Excellent specially from detective Park playing by the great Kang-ho Song , the cinematography also was amazing, the line story almost to be perfect but the second half had a little problem, but otherwise the movie is blowing your mind, Definitely Memories of Murder Deserve your time my friend.

This movie is not for the kind of audience, who doesn't understand the depth of stories.Even though it didn't end well, but still have a meaning to it, which some may not understand or just not satisfied with it
if you like a movie which completes at the end and didn't left you with a thought or doubt, then this isn't for you.

reviews.review_title: It's more like living a brilliant novel
reviews.content: You will love it if you liked "Se7en". Lots of details but in an interesting and exciting way. You would start to think and investigate with the detectives during the movie, also the viewer will model and build-up stereotypes about the mystery and about the characters. However, during the script, the characters develop and the director deliver that brilliantly, you'll gradually change your mind of them and start to like some and dislike some. The ending is alluring, absolutely unpredictable and fascinating. Here the director also successes in achieving his goals in tempting the viewer.The viewer may notice the continual scenes and gestures on the situation in Korea back then in 1980s.Critics may say the movie contains obvious insurmountable odds, but with these, there will be not such a great movie.8/10 : Not 10 because personally, I believe it could be made better, moreover I was not satisfied by the end of the film. During the last minutes, I expected much more than the story gives.

reviews.review_title: One of the best movie i've ever seen !
reviews.content: A serial killing movie where the detectives try to catch the killer but every time they failed & get confused about the murderer. they catch some suspect & start questioning. when you'll watch this movie you probably think that every suspect can be the killer according to their behavior & answers. the main two lead roles acted amazingly. their natural acting will touch your heart & the cinematography will make you think about re-watching this masterpiece. this is a slow paced movie where the story slowly get paced & you'll see the characters will blossom & disappear like flowers, that's what made this movie a masterpiece. at the end of the show you'll question yourself & think about this movie whole day. this is just brilliant ! i give it 10/10.

reviews.review_title: Weird at first glance, but stunning after watching
reviews.content: As is common with many Asian movies, we Europeans (Americans even more) find them a bit weird. All the crazy fighting scenes and unusual characters met with a rather odd sense of humour. This movie is no different. But that doesn't change the fact that it is an amazing piece of cinematography.The plot is based on a true story, a series of murders that happened between 1986 and 1991 in South Korea and the three detectives investigating the case. The movie is powerful from the very first scene and you soon realise this will be one of those "beautiful" movies that stay with you for awhile. The music is spectacular,the scenery is warm, the characters grow on you, but on the same note, the movie stays on firm ground, giving you a sense of seriousness and realism. The 2 different poles, so rarely combined in movies in a right way, are done superbly in Memories of murder, thus making this film seriously good.Worth watching, but with an open mind. This is not a Hollywood movie.

Very disappointing thriller from the director of Parasite. As is common in Asian cop films the cops seem too stupid to have ever been hired much less ever made detective. The plot is silly, hinging on a sappy pop song. The film looks good at least.

In Memories of Murder, Bong Joon Ho makes the audience feel the uncertainty and frightfullness the characters feel. This film has everything, with commentary on human nature to Korean politics. The directing and cinematography is absolutely beautiful, giving many shots of our main characters together in frame to show both their differences and similarities. The story is gripping all throughout, giving every character an arc, and the ending is absolutely astounding, if not all that satisfying. Bong Joon Ho put in years of work and it completely shows in this film.

reviews.review_title: Pretty good & it certainly has its moments but...
reviews.content:
It certainly has its moments!, but I wouldn't go as far as to call it a masterpiece, citizen x's distant cousin, you can feel the detective's desperation, people dying and them not being able to prevent it or do anything about it and getting no closer to finding the killer. As I said, my two cents, it's pretty good but by no means a masterpiece.
And well..., the ending was a bit anticlimactic, good but you kind of sigh and go "so that's what happened in real life, that's horrible!" and then you'll get your mobile and check the movie's wikipedia page

reviews.review_title: A slice of mystery to your comfort.
reviews.content: Mysteries! I have always found comfort in them, its assuring to know that someone cares enough to demystify. Murder mysteries in their own way uphold humanity and truth. In each of the mysteries a detective cares to detect the truth by listening, observing and finally acting upon to solve the crime.Memories of Murder a film on a heinous crime goes on to become my comfort film. It has rain, mud, mad people, bad people, good cop, bad cop, old women, young women, past, future, almost all opposites are laid in front of you in a timeline.This film is perhaps one of few that can lay down the universality of people and society.
I thought it was boring, when I started watching the first 15 minutes, but I went back to give it a rewatch. And it was amazing.

reviews.review_title: One of the best crime films i've ever seen
reviews.content: The beginning of the film was beautiful and catchy. The plot was interesting from beginning to end. In the middle of the movie i saw some parts that were kinda bored, but was to connect to another interesting event. The murders, the way they were made and all the clues and detail of them were the most absorbing thing of the movie. Very recommended crime movie.

Memories of Murder is a beautiful film by Bong Joon-Ho that takes you on a slow-paced ride in a small province located in South Korea. The setting adds an eerie feeling to the film and sets the tone from the first scene. It's a slow film, but it's very enjoyable and gripping from start to finish. I recommend you watch this film, it's on same level as Zodiac and other great mystery-thrillers about serial killers.

reviews.review_title: How does a murderer look like?
reviews.content: I had this movie in my stock for quite a long time and i have just finished watching it.Have to say the best murder mystery i have ever seen. It was oldboy which made me believe that korean movies can be as good as the movies being made in any part of world.Now i just want to thank it.I have never had such an amazing experience before.Only seven comes a bit close.The movie starts of with couple of dead bodies found one after another.You see park as an immature detective dealing with the case in first 20 minutes or so.Then enters detective seo from the city of seoul to assist him.Park doesn't like seo first and then story moves on from the tension in between them to the frustration of not being able to solve the case.The movie will suck you into the investigation.You can feel the frustration the helplessness of the detectives.The condition of Korea didn't help them a bit either.Some scenes like the chasing scene on the stroke of the hour and the climax are so brilliantly done that they will literally sweep you away.Joon-ho bong's direction is impeccable.All of the actors specially the 2 main leads kang-ho song & sang-kyung kim are brilliant.A must watch.How does a murderer look like?Can you see into someone's eyes and tell if he is a murderer?No you can't.

Best murder mystery and very grounded. The cinematography is just amazing, the long one take shots are so good than u will feel fpp mode instead of tpp sometimes. In the climax the shot , near tunnel is freaking good. Music, performance and direction is out of the box as we expect from Bong Joon-ho's movie.
You won't find out who the killer is and that's what i came for. I don't care if it's based on a true story.
Greyness. A film that leaves you with a hole. A movie where you're with the detectives the whole time. You never leave that sense of who did it. A credit to the actors and directors.

I was surprised by the amount of jokes in a crime mystery movie like this. At the same time it was gripping and end of the seat thriller. By the end of the movie you understand how the events have the power to change a person completely. As compared to The Zodiac, this movie was better suspense wise. A few questions are left unanswered apart from the main question. I wish they didn't tell us about it right at the start of this movie. Karma is real and it works in mysterious way maybe we will never be able to completely understand. I wonder what happened to the serial killer and what his reaction was when he saw the movie or if he ever had the chance.

reviews.review_title: A murder mystery of the familiar crime genre but with an unfamiliar ending.
reviews.content:
It tells us the story behind the first ever serial murders in the history of Korea. It does so in a very engaging way with induced portions of social satire and comedy.
Even though it is Bong Joon-ho's second film only as a director, the brilliance of his screenplay and direction can be seen very clearly in the utmost realistic approach that the movie takes.
The best thing to talk about would be the performances. The realism in the movie and the desperation of the main characters was portrayed successfully by the brilliant cast, especially Song kang-ho and his incredible performance.
Cinematography is actually quite decent. The musical score elevated few already suspenseful scenes up another notch and reminded me of the scores in Alfred Hitchcock movies.Positives : Bong Joon-ho, Song Kang-ho, Music, Cinematography.
Negatives : The ending may not feel satisfactory for certain audience and will leave you longing for more.

This is one of the movies that got me into looking for South Korean movies from the local library. I followed up with Mother from the same director and never looked back. Great storytelling, and acting.

Completely wasted my 2 hours.After 2 hours, the film ended without knowing who is the murderer. It's like fooling your viewers.Every murder mysetery should culminate with revealing who actually the murderer is. But this one is a complete disaster. You waited 2 hours and in the end, we do not know who is the murderer.Complete dissapointment.

reviews.review_title: You might have to spend some thinking about it.
reviews.content: Most of the people proclaimed this an instantaneous masterpiece. For me, however, this was not the case. Initially, the ending felt unsatisfactory to me and I was so tired I slept after finishing it.Thinking about it now, it does seem that this movie is a great thriller worth watching, with extraordinary camera shots, such as the world famous foggy field scene, the introduction of the main detective, and the overall gloomy and dark colour grading. While the movie did start out slow, it was not the way it ended, while also getting sidetracked into some dark humour and casual violence.But the storyline, the emotions, the initial acute airheadedness of the main detective, while also his development, are what I remember the most from this movie. Particularly the last 10 minutes when detective Seo realises the girl he met and helped was raped and murdered. How he began to lose his mind with anger and rage, and how detective Park, now mature and sensible, pulled him back from the edge while the same Park at the beginning of the movie, would have let Seo blow the guy's brains out. It was pure raw emotion.For me, this wasn't a masterpiece, but it stood out from the other thrillers I've watched till now. Yet who knows? Maybe it'll become a masterpiece for me too if I spend enough time with it.

Simply awesome movie. Worth to watch.
Best psycho thriller in world cinema.

One of the greatest storytellings of all the time.The story and character developing and the way how things happen is more important than finding the murderer or how things end. Amazing and real performances can blow your mind.

Really weak film I was quite surprised. Unfathomly stupid policemen beating up any suspect and telling them what they should admit to. One policeman from the capital begins to inject some thought into the investigation by soon gives up. So no interesting detective work going on. No story developed. Character's uninteresting. And to reiterate the police are impossibly stupid, and not in a comical way. They beat up a mentally handicapped man to force a confession and then are surprised when they find out he didn't do it. Do the film makers think the audience are stupid too?
Even tho i thought the movie was really good, it would've been so much better if it was clear who the murder was, we just get to have our own opinions and thoughts and I didn't quite like that.

This is hands down my favourite movie I have seen it 5 times in one month. Just because I want to watch it with every friend I have. Just... just you know close this website and go watch it. Do yourself a favor.
The movie is great till the end. But the ending sucks.

This is probably one of the best foreign crime thrillers I've seen in a while if not one of the best in the world. Beautifully shot with a very engaging lead actor, the film makes the viewer think.What makes this movie so amazing is not just the acting or the direction or the lights and camera effects but the feelings that each character shows. The emotions are so raw and real that you become a part of this narration. Humans are full of flaws and we help other's detect their flaws and eventually we ourselves succumb to our flaw's. The world in which we live is sometimes so shocking, disturbing and beyond comprehension that we have to eventually give in and not relentlessly chase our pursuits how much ever flawless and meticulous we are in our tasks.It's a beautiful film and worthy of any cinephile to check out!

The korean film " Memories of a murder " by Joon-ho Bong follows the story of three detectives as they try to catch a serial-killer who rapes and murders women in a small town in Korea.
This film is directed so perfectly by Bong who does an amazing job in staging a lot of characters in each scene but focusing on the important parts of the scene.
The performances are also great as all three detectives are put through a lot of difficulties . There are a lot of emotional moments and you really feel for the characters even though they are terrible persons ( they even torture the suspects! and watching them trying desperately to fing the killer and how much this affects their lives is truly incredible.Also i have to mention the ending. Without spoiling it , it is truly haunting and unforgettable and it sums up the film perfectly .Memories of murder is one the best films i've seen and is up there with se7en as my favorite mystery movie .
10/10

Keystone cops meets twin peaks if you can imagine that. Faces carry the story. Of constant failure to solve the puzzle of evil in society. An evil femicide and idiot men who refuse to actually think and feel. So an ego busting story, step by step. Beautifully shot and the rain keeps falling.

reviews.review_title: One of the very best crime movies
reviews.content: It's rather spoilt my appreciation of any other Joon-ho Bong movies, having seen this first. This is right up there with all the best (American) crime movies of recent memory; Seven, Silence of the Lambs, Usual Suspects, Prisoners, LA Confidential... Untold extra points for being the only one that's not even really about the murders at all. And that last scene. WOW.

This guy BONG JOON HO, he is one of the most Genious directors I have ever seen. Noone can match his story telling. reviews.review_title: Greatest mystery movie of all time
reviews.content: This movie, hands down, is the greatest mystery movie of all time.The movie isn't so much about finding the rapist, whom as you all know, hasn't been caught to this day (edited: just caught in 2019 from an unrelated case initially).It's about the struggle the two detectives went through in finding the rapist, how the psychology of the two switched as the movie progressed; the movie brilliantly showed how the Seoul detective turned from a highly logical and methodical detective who only believed in hard evidence into a desperate detective who was driven only by emotion and revenge while his partner whom in the beginning was very laid back and simply trusted his "look-me-in-the-eye" method, became increasingly responsible and thoughtful at the end.The ending scene was brilliant in so many ways. We can see from Park's facial expression how frustrated and regretful he was for not being able to catch the bad guy and especially after learning from the little girl that the guy he had been chasing all this time was in fact just an ordinary looking person, as opposed to some weird, bald, monstrous looking guy that he had had in his mind throughout the investigation.He later looked into the camera with his "look me in the eye" face, knowing that the rapist was still out there and hoping that he would be watching this and felt a little bit of guilt. The movie then fades away with a haunting and despairing music, a perfect accompaniment to the regretful detectives for not being able to solve the case, to the desperate audience for not seeing the actual bad guy, and to the rapist himself for the gruesome crime that he has to live for the rest of his lives.10/10.
Heart wrenching, on the the edge yet relaxed with great direction and screenplay accompanied with top notch acting of the leads. One will be immersed in the experience and is a must watch.

Memories of Murder is gripping and tense, while also unexpectedly hilarious. I enjoyed watching it throughout, but the ending left me frustrated. To be fair, it is based upon real-life events so not too much can be done to fix that.
Tense and droll at the same time, with some dark outright humor popping up unexpectedly at times. Don't expect any kind of regular whodunit, the cops here are barely able to understand their jobs.

A thrilling mystery story that leaves you guessing just as much as the detectives are. Memories of Murder is often unpredictable, following the chase and lead of three very distinct detective personalities while including the not often scene slapstick and satire. The multiple leads combined with the swift shift from funny to sobering is like a rollercoaster. Bong delivers a captivating and suspenseful chase, while keeping the pathos real. The ending is also absolutely haunting and makes the film timeless and complete - but is it?

Skillfully blending multiple genres, this is a typically engaging and hard-to-forget film from Bong Joon Ho. As much about the fissures in society as it is about crime, not to mention the perceptions we have of ourselves and each other, the depiction of a chaotic and desperate hunt for a serial killer is gripping, laced with comedy and deeply insightful. The artfulness of the film is subtle and almost hypnotic; the brilliant score works with the saturated colour of the bulk of the film to create a strange, unsettling and beautiful effect. Undoubtedly up there with the director's best work, this will worm under your skin and nag at your consciousness long after watching.
Annoying characters, and despite being based on truth goes absolutely nowhere

Memories of Murder is a fantastic detective movie, made by Bong Joon Ho and his team. The movie follows a series of murders, which all look like the action of one man, however it is not a 100% clear who did it and why he did it. The movie has some gorgeous cinematography, that reminded me a lot of David Fincher his work, especially Zodiac of course.  While I like a movie as Zodiac a bit more then Memories of Murder, there is no doubting that this movie is fantastic. The performances of everybody are really great, however the atmosphere of the film, is what worked the best for me personally. The movie starts a bit slow for me personally, but when you get in the 2nd and especially 3rd act, the movie shines. The ending of Memories of Murder was fantasticly done, which as well reminded me a lot of Fincher his work, with this case being Se7en. Overall a movie really worth your time, especially if you are a fan of the detective genre!
it's just a rollercoaster of emotions it's crazy how good this movie is.

This moody, stylish, and inconclusive serial killer investigation film traces the investigation into a series of ongoing and gruesome murders. At times the investigation is played for laughs, and the torturous tactics of the detectives are almost as scary as the killings. The detectives are changed by their job, one seemingly driven crazy by it, going from a belief in evidence and reports over hunches and theories to the exact opposite - dismissing DNA evidence in favour of a gut feeling. By focusing on the investigators to the exclusion of the killer, this presents a new twist on the genre.

This movie has a kind of overcast and pressing tone which fits very well. The characters we follow are quite unorthodox when it comes to this type of detective story, and it adds a layer of uniqueness as well as uncertainty. The movie is well directed, and some scenes are very successfully creepy and ominous. It also has an interesting conclusion that leaves a lot up to interpretation. While I usually don't like when movies are too vague, the questions the movie poses were framed in an interesting way here that made up for it.

Whatever the fact may be about those people on which the story is based, the characters here are so unbearably moronic that there's hardly room for anything else to cause the drama. They act plain stupid, consistently, there's close to nothing to be learned about the murderers psychology simply because the detectives are caught up in their slapstick stupidity. A little less effort to make them look silly would have helped the topics complexity quite a lot, but the exact amount here I guess is what Bongs trademark is, and it takes away from everything. Overrated. Cinematic garbage with very little substance but a whole lot of potential to be annoying. If people were that stupid, well that actually could make a murderer—and that would be the answer to Park Doo-man's question to the suspect in the end: how he can live like that...
A brilliantly directed, slow paced investigation piece that is frequently funny and quietly haunting.

Wait wait wait, am I the kid who saw the king naked? The movie is a literal disaster in every imaginable way! I don't care who's the director, I don't care about your big philosophical words! I'm telling you the movie is a disaster!

Another Bong Joon-ho banger! Unlike the slick serial killer detective thrillers of the time, this one is grimey, sad, and shows the monotony that goes into investigating such a hard to capture target. It also doesn't shy away from the desperate measures police will go to, to just make pieces fit. It does all this while somehow still managing to be humorous as well.

Set in Korea in 1986, detectives are frantically trying to solve the growing pile of rape/murders perpetrated by seemingly one assailant.  Bong Joon Ho directs this fascinating and sometimes hilarious efforts of the detectives who set their sights on one young man who seems to have knowledge of the murders.  Really well made and riveting crime/mystery.
A brilliantly directed, slow paced investigation piece that is frequently funny and quietly haunting.

"Paper doesn't lie."

A tense and engaging investigational thriller that employs plenty of the film design that Bong Joon-Ho has become renowned for - subtext regarding political and social satire interwoven with creative narratives that have enough strength to stand on their own legs. The plot, ostensibly about coming to understand the psyche of an unprecedented killer, really revolves around two key facets, the changing social landscape of South Korea (particularly the political instability that factors into bureacratic ineptitude embodied by Song Kang-ho's Park Doo-man, and the self-defeating strongman tactics employed by his junior, Cho Yong-koo) and a more universal human frailty. While the former investigators rely on their familiarity with local customs and even traditional superstition where their wits fail them, Kim Sang-kyung's Seo Tae-yoon is the more urban, procedural investigator embodying a new way of thinking. Together there is an overlapping goal (catching the killer), but plenty of friction caused by the disparity in their approaches and a surprising amount of humor in the contrast between them in spite of the seriousness of their roles.

Ultimately an exercise showcasing the inability of completely rectifying contrasting lifestyles (Park and Seo gradually form a collaborative effort, but are unsuccesful in catching the killer; a 'coming together to save the day' ending would have seemed cheap), Memories of Murder paints an uncertain portrait for the future of a socially divided South Korea filled with people who are imperfect by nature, but also is one particularly taut crime thriller. There's little in the way of audience omnipotence, except a few scattered moments to keep the tension high. The framing, cinematography, and color design all seem way ahead of their time for 2003; this film could easily be released today. The performances are solid, the direction is taut, and the characters/character development are excellent. And what an ending shot, with Song Kang-ho directing his 'eye contact' method to the audience. 

Definitely an influence on Zodiac, but miles better in my opinion. Where Fincher skews towards the true-to-life elements to give the audience a chill and a sense of mystery, Bong Joon-ho clearly has loftier ambitions. (4.5/5)

Memories of Murder is a top-tier murder mystery thriller. This film has painfully flawed characters (who you're rooting for), depressing subject matter, edge-of-your-seat action, and is beautifully shot. The first interrogation scene grabbed my attention; the "murder reenactment" scene made me realize that I was watching something special. The character development of Park (Song Kang-ho) and Seo (Kim Sang-kyung) culminates in a penultimate scene that catches your breath in your throat. We catch a glimpse of the killer — in a blurry, frightening moment — but not enough to identify him. The suspect carousel, the puzzle-piece clues, the fear and distrust fomenting in the provincial town create the tension on which the plot thrives. The story is based on a series of real murders in Korea that have been compared to the "Zodiac Killer" in America. In 2003, the murders had not yet been solved, so the ending is powerful and makes sense. However, in only the past few years, that has changed. Memories of Murder is a fantastic movie and has at least three jump-kicks. Hellz yeah.

This is a very good film, one that works on many different levels that can be dissected and analyzed, I wish I was smart enough to see them all. What stood out to me this time was the compositions and beautiful shots, the foggy wheat fields, rain drizzling down muddy streets, lights glowing and bouncing off the wet grass it’s beautifully dark and gritty with an ominous atmosphere. Bong has a lot to say about the very masculine, totalitarian threat looming over us. Democracy isn’t always permanent and a past with this many systemic issues as can be a very real future. I read that he watched Cure repeatedly while writing this and you can see the influence. In that film there’s much more emphasis on the psyche and digging deep into each of our darkest desires, how easily those can be twisted into gruesome acts of violence given a little pressure. In Memories of Murder, there’s a different but similar kind of digging. Less of our darkest, suppressed societal desires but the fact those desires exist and are manifested in a setting where murders like this were never expected to happen. How dismantling and confusing the thought of an evil you never imagined existed affects your mind. How the simplest looking of people can do the most grotesque things. The arrogance that this idea was never considered, or taken seriously and had the impact it did, is, in my opinion, what the film is built on. The police don't expect the killer to be a simple man, yet he is (on the outside), and that’s the scariest thing he could’ve been. One of my all time favorites, thank you Bongster for this banger. Cannot wait for whatever he does next.

A very interesting case worthy of being told through film, and one told quite well at that. The plot was well planned and impactful, but the amount of beating and idiotic policing did become wearing as time went on. Furthermore, the detective from Seoul wasn't as professional nor as intelligent as I expected, although his actions towards the end made sense and allowed for a brilliant scene. It would have been nice to have more background on him considering there was some backstory to the original investigator and then a slight focus on his pal. Aside from that and the perhaps overly comedic tone in places, it seemed to correspond to the actual events well, and the actor for the perpetrator even looked like the real person, despite the case still being unsolved when the film was made. They nailed the perpetrator's behaviour, the ending was excellent, and it will certainly be a film I remember. The pacing was reasonable besides the dragging police corruption, the acting was solid, plenty happened, the action was a mixture of enjoyable, comedic, and tragic, the cinematography and visual effects held up and made Korea look beautiful despite the events, the production design was believable, and the soundtrack was catchy and emotional.

A brilliantly dark yet hilarious look into the minds of a few blundering Korean detectives going head to head with a more measured logical thinking outside partner. Cinematography is stunning as Bong Joon-ho movies usually are. Song Kang-Ho was tremendous and absolutely hilarious, Kim Sang-Kyung was equally as masterful in his portrayal, as were the remainder of the leading actors and actresses. I absolutely loved this movie, I had high expectations going in but my expectations were surpassed by the hilarity and storytelling that unfolded. 100/100

"Memories of Murder" is Bong Joon-Ho's second feature film. He took a while to have the notion of pace, the first act is too long and a little boring, but from the second act onwards, the script starts to show its layers and the development is fantastic. It's more than a movie about a crime, it's a battle of egos inside the police [the veteran local policeman (Detective Park, Song Kang-Ho) versus the young policeman with more knowledge from the big city (Detective Seo, Kim Sang-Kyung)] and how a very difficult case can wear out these guys physically and psychologically (something well-shown by Kim Roi-Ha's character). The suspects are amazing and give material to make the audience think if they're guilty or innocent, especially Park No-Shik (Kwang-Ho) and Park Hae-Il (Hyeon-Gyu). I won't develop anything more because this type of film doesn't allow a deep approach without spoilers.

Very interesting and thrilling, with a definite commitment to realism in all aspects that you can definitely appreciate. I have a slight problem with Bon Joon-ho's endings, in that they're all very sad and give the film an overall feeling of pointless. But I thought this particular ending was maybe a little bit clever, knowing the real story.

Korean crime film where girls are being murdered and the investigators are stumped. The character development of the suspects and the investigators is well done...and the realistic (and frustrating) ending is on point.
Well produced but seen it all before. Shades of the zodiac and multiple other detective cases. Fine to watch but fairly forgettable.
A crime mystery film that is totally different from what you'd expect from an American or a European one and that's a good thing.
The best Korean movie.

Bong Joon Ho's sophomore effort, Memories of Murder, is a brooding and haunting film that, despite its slow pace, is mesmerizing from start to finish.  Filmed in muted tones, the movie follows detectives as they investigate a series of murders attributed to a serial killer who, despite a defined modus operandi, manages to elude police.  Even at this early stage in his career, Bong proves himself to be a cinematic master, each shot perfectly framed and blocked.  Despite the oppressive atmosphere throughout, there are flashes of humor as the investigators bumble their way through unmanaged and contaminated crime scenes in their effort to uncover the identity of the killer.  It's a slow burning police procedure and a great primer for the Bong films that followed.

Exceptional- this is Bong Joon-Ho's remarkable film about the hunt for a serial killer in 1980's rural South Korea. Read David Ehrlich's wonderfully insightful, perceptive writing on the movie that says far more than I have in me right now. 4 stars

Appropriately watched with the recent release of Parasite (2020) to Blu-ray and DVD, Memories of a Murder is one of Bong Joon-ho's earlier features, but there's no mistaking his handprints all over the story as he tackles class and culture amongst a serial killer thriller. As a big-city cop helps two inept local law enforcement officers to track down the killer, director Bong's magician like approach to interweaving story and political agenda amidst some truly funny sequences makes this a very important stepp

At the end of the film, I was left confused, but that isn't necessarily a bad thing. While I did end up confused, I couldn't help but find myself engaged and entagled in this mysterious series of events. Not once in it's 131 minute runtime did it feel like it was dragging on for the purpose of taking up reel space. Bong Joon-ho managed to extract some of the most genuine acting I've seen to where I wouldn't blame you if you thought this was real. Everyone in the film, despite being just a set of characters, felt like a very real person, and in a sense, they might as well be, as the film was based on a real set of investigations. The scenes of abuse are just as shocking as was necessary, and help to drive home Bong Joon-Ho's point about the Republic of Korea's justice system (at least during 1986-1991). The music really suits each of the scenes well, and I could just go on and on. Ultimately, though, I was blown away by this movie, and I can not help but give it a perfect 5 stars out of 5. Among people who are williing to get over the barrier of foreign language films, this will easily be an instantaneous classic for years to come.
really great, although we dont get all the anwers

Heartfelt, Sad, Gross, Beautiful, Tragic. This movie is a roller coaster. It a dark depressing premise, but with a great cast, fantastic direction it becomes relatable. You are swept up into this story and you are rooting for the good guys to finally get a win.

In every anime trio there's a serious one with two clowns. Same as this one.

A crime thriller where three desperate detectives investigated a serial crime. The first one-third was, in Bong Joon-Ho style, very funny where Kang-Ho Song's character acted like a clown with silly detective moves and deductions. 

After that, the movie became serious with characters going downhill and became more desperate for answers. It's not the most mind-blowing story, until the ending. If I was born in South Korea and knew about the case or lived through the period, this movie would have had a much bigger impact on me. Doing some research afterward and I realized how profound and powerful that last shot was.

Overall, another great work from Bong Joon-Ho. 8/10

A classic korean movie directed by Bong Joon-ho, director of the well acclaimed movie 'Parasite'. The movie is set in a small town where two inept detectives try to catch a serial killer.
The acting is amazing! Each scene is captivating and intense. You might need to adjust to the subtitles at first but the movie is worth the trouble (you can always pause and read the difficult lines)
This movie is good for all those who like korean movies and those who are thinking to start watching to know what all the hype is about 😉

An entertaining and intriguing murder mystery story, combined with Ho's direction, the script he co-wrote with Shim, the performances of the cast, Iwashiro's score, Kim's cinematography, Kim's editing, Ryu's production design, Yang's set decoration, Kim's costume design, action sequences, sound design and production values, Memories Of Murder is a brilliant representation of the deep quality that Asian cinema profoundly possesses!!!
An elegantly directed, well executed, strangely humorous and thought provoking movie which traces the thin line separating the murderer from the murdered.
It's safer to go into a stranger's basement in the Bay Area than to go out on a rainy night in rural Korea.

This was one of the few remaining Bong films I had yet to see and it certainly did not disappoint.

I love his touch and appreciate his use of symbolism which resides in much of his work. This is probably what drives an urge in me to rewatch his films shortly after, knowing that I will gain even more insight as more layers are hopefully penetrated with each watch.

I definitely had goosebumps at a few moments in this film and it never hurts to nail the ending as well.
Memories of Murder is an incredible, masterful cinematic interpretation of a murder mystery that will shake you to your core.

You can really see the influence this must have had on David Finchers Zodiac. The direction, score and cinematography are all sublime. The film took me a while to get into but once it got a hold of me it wouldn't let go. A fantastic early effort from future Parasite director Bong Joon-ho.

"Memories of Murder" is a film that had a huge resurgence after 2019's hit, "Parasite." I am a big fan of these sort of these dark crime mysteries and enjoyed this movie. It is more of a slow burn but because it is inspired by a real-life story, it is consistently fascinating. The open-ended nature of the movie is a circumstance of when it was made and it honestly makes the movie chilling by the time it wraps up. I think the most similar Hollywood counterpart to this movie is David Fincher's "Zodiac" but I think this movie is more engaging than that one despite similarities. Overall, this is an unsettling and effectively made serial killer story that is worth watching for genre fans.

Beautiful opening and tracking shots at the beginning in the wheat fields. Very interesting mood and tone. The themes are serious but it doesn't seem to take itself too serious, lending itself to a more lighthearted feel. I love how Bong nailed the whole 80's fashion and look throughout the movie. Man, Bong really knows how to setup a beautiful shot. This movie's a dark comedy. 

Wow, so they're trying to convict an innocent retarded kid as the murderer just so they can say that they solved the case, so they can move on? That's so corrupt and crooked. So funny when they bought the kid NICE sneakers instead of NIKE. Jesus, wtf is going on during that time in 1986? There's like military presence on the streets? Is that why these cops are able to do what they do? Drop kicking suspects and acting ruthlessly reckless. How darkly ironic that the detective that tortures suspects with his military boots, now has to have his right leg amputated. The same one who would cover up his right boot with a sleeve to not leave and scratches when he was curb stomping people on the floor. That's karmic justice right there lol. 

I like the detective from Seoul's character. He seems like he's out for justice and wants to see things through the right way. I think it was Park who committed the crimes. He was the only one who retaliated out of all the suspects. I mean he had a gun pointed at his face and he took a rock and slashed the inspector's hand! If that were any other innocent suspect, they would have cowered in fear, plead for their life. And just the way he looked like he enjoyed saying that he did the murders is a telling sign. The document at the end saying that there's no DNA proof that it was Park is just Bong's way of saying how incompetent, unhelpful and unreliable America can be when helping other countries. 

Bong uses subtlety and creepiness in a very effective way by either blurring something in the background or by building tension. Works as a very offbeat and quirky comedy at times, definitely has its own style going on. I will say Bong Joon-Ho definitely has a great sense of humor. I didn't find the color of the movie that pleasing. It has like a greenish grayish tone that makes everything seem more somber, almost artificial in a way. There's some clever social commentary and satire going on here with military and police power. I feel like I need to rewatch this movie again at some point.
A masterful crime thriller that mix's all the great elements of Silence of the Lambs, with comedy, and social themes. Pure Bong Joon Ho.

Haunting portrayal of the atrocities committed by South Korea's Zodiac Killer.

Bong Joon-ho's South Korean crime drama and murder mystery Memories of Murder (2003) is a fascinating, informative, and disturbing depiction of the 1986-1991 serial killings commited in Hwaseong, Gyeonggi Province. It's startling as it documents the intense and insane homicide detective investigation that was undertaken over years to identify Korea's first documented serial killer. You see enough to disturb your mind and infer what has happened. The film leaves you changed with a sense of the apathetic cruelty that humanity is capable of, yet the decency of good people trying to do their jobs balancing out the evil violence.

I should mention that it's a disgusting case, finally concluded all these years later as the real killer finally confessed in 2019, which Bong obviously didn't know about as the film released in 2003, but it adds a layer of satisfaction knowing that he has been caught. I think Memories of Murder is one of the greatest pictures I've ever seen, one of South Korea's best films, and a peerless crime drama. Only The Silence of the Lambs, Se7en, Cure, or Zodiac can truly compare in craftsmanship and chills. Memories of Murder is in a class all its own for its raw realism and sleek direction.

Bong Joon-ho's direction is riveting as he details the entire police investigation in shocking true crime with heavy rainfall, long takes, and creepy atmosphere everywhere. Director Bong uses the cover of nightfall, shadows, dark paths, and eerie forestry to unnerve the viewer as the grisly details are unveiled. It's shocking to see any crime of this grotesque and cruel nature, let along hearing someone speak the facts right to you. Bong builds the detective's case with facts, suspects, time, evidence, motive, and connects the dots between the killings so that we can easily draw the same conclusions as Korea's law enforcement at the time.

Furthermore, Bong contributes his own added absurdist sense of humor as there's plenty to laugh at to lighten the mood of this seriously horrifying case. I was surprised at how funny Memories of Murder starts out as these detectives tried anything and everything from torture to shamans to figure out who the killer was, but it evolves into an astonishing display of enthralling deduction and reasoning alongside brutal killings. 

Song Kang-ho is hilarious as the immoral and insane cop with a ruthless attitude Detective Park Doo-man. You see the Korean government's brutal and outdated tactics with his character, especially with his countryside cop methods. Song Kang-ho is perfect here as he also displays his dramatic prowess towards the end as he gets more seriously involved in the case. Likewise, Kim Sang-kyung is excellent as Seoul Detective Seo Tae-yoon with his big city methodology and cool seriousness. You understand that Detectives Park and Seo needed to work together with their combined unorthodox and by the book, respectively, techniques. They are incredible leading actors in Memories of Murder, especially once the camera is right up on their eyes.

Kim Roe-ha's erratic and violence police officer is both fun and shocking as he tortures suspects in interrogation for false confessions and worthless testimony as Detective Cho Yong-koo. Song Jae-ho is funny and bears a strong presence as Sergeant Shin Dong-chul with his gravitas and experience. I liked Park No-shik's funny performance as the mentally challenged witness Baek Kwang-ho. I must mention the cold and captivating performance from Park Hae-il as serial killer suspect Park Hyeon-gyu. I should say that Go Seo-hee is beautiful and compelling as Officer Kwon Kwi-ok. Jeon Mi-seon is lovely and captivating as the endearing Kwok Seol-yung, similarly.

Writers Bong Joon-ho, Kim Kwang-rim, and Shim Sung-bo find the humanity of these detectives getting pushed into the dark oblivion of hopelessness from optimistic beginnings. It's terrifying to watch them unravel. Bong Joon-ho amazed me with his delightful satire Parasite, but Memories of Murder remains his finest masterclass of refined direction and his greatest picture.

Kim Sun-min's editing keeps you absorbed by the mystery with quickly developing clues and sharp cuts from detectives to the murder's perspective for an all encompassing 131 minutes of mayhem. Kim Hyung-koo's cinematography is breathtaking with ultra wide shots of the paddy fields hiding a killer to the serial killer lurking up in the shadows of a treetop. Everything is on screen for you to see and enjoy. Ryu Seong-hie's production design impressively recreates 1986 Korea, while Yang Hong-sam's set decoration looks all gritty and grungy for the furnishings.

Taro Iwashiro's score is beautiful with an ever increasing sense of dread to his composition. Kim Yoo-seon's costumes have a natural look with a cute fashion sense that comes across as fun for such a dreary picture. Jong Ik Kang comes up with all manner of striking visual effects for gunshots and needle injections.

In conclusion, there's depraved humanity and then there's humanity's aptitude for creating beautiful art like Bong Joon-ho's Memories of Murder.
classic ! best Korea movie ever

While it may seem a slow burn at first, Memories of Murder is a film that slowly enthralls you and engages you until you are fully immersed in what is happening and you realize that you are watching a masterpiece in the thriller genre.

Memories of Murder is about a detective team who tries to solve a series of rape-murder crimes(Its based on a true events). Cinematography was through the roof , every scene was perfectly made. For a crime drama had really funny scenes to it and it was kind unexpected. One of Bong Joon-Ho's first big hits is now available for rent on Amazon Prime! The film, based on a true crime story that was not solved at the time of the film's original release, is about the efforts of some local detectives to find a serial killer. Two detectives from a local police department, one of who has anger control issues, and the other who seems to have gotten his training from crime detective television shows, are joined by an educated detective from Seoul. The first half of the film is very funny watching Detective Park conjure all of his worst and amateur sleuthing skills, even visiting a psychic, to make headway in the crime. As typical with Joon-Ho's films, his stories linger along the cultural boundaries, and in this case, he finds humor in the contrast in investigating styles between the three detectives. There are shifts in mood that are also characteristic of his films. You find yourself laughing and then suddenly realize something horribly serious is happening. And, like Parasite, the noticeable divisions between the characters blur as the story continues and the murder investigation leads nowhere. This is a well-crafted crime story that is beautifully shot and wonderfully acted. While I don't know a lot about Korean history, it was interesting to watch these events unfold in a culture that seemed to not have any experience with serial killers and where the police didn't have time to dedicate resources to fighting the crime because they were out covering demonstrations and focusing on "other priorities". I loved this film, which gets a huge thumbs up from me. It is excellent entertainment and is one of my favorite films of his.

While there are the occasional convenient plot devices, they are far outweighed by the smart directing and storytelling. This is the kinda of movie making we need more of, imo. By only complaint is the drab yet understandable color palette.
Western audiences might not like the end, but Memories of Murder is a deeply human meditation on justice and victimization in modern  society.

Bong Joon-ho and the fantastic cast have created something very engaging here. SERIAL BONG
After "Parasite" mania, it was inevitable that Bong Joon-ho's past film catalogue would trickle across the ocean. With "Memories of Murder", we receive his classic 2003 serial murder mystery, which in spite of being only his second feature, is a strong rival for his best work. Though compared favourably to David Fincher's excellent "Zodiac", this cracker Korean film came four years prior.

Based on real life events that gripped South Korea back in the late eighties, this riveting thriller delivers Bong's clever filmmaking touches, mixing pull no punches drama with deft comedic bits to create a rich viewing experience. Whether the small village cops slapsticking and bungling a gruesome crime scene, or brutally extorting confessions from the innocent, they do so in a flowing, organic rhythm of tone shifts that is key to the movie going experience.

Parasite star Song Kang-ho is excellent as the rowdy, cocksure detective who claims to reveal criminals by looking deep into their eyes. He is the perfect blend of boisterous, naive, silly, gung ho and empathetic. As with most Bong projects, such sublime character development is crucial to the plot.

The less said about the storyline the better (and the real story has some interesting recent revelations). Best left to discover that on your own. "Memories of Murder" defies the "early effort" tagline. It is a fully developed, beautifully shot, perfectly paced, and gripping film, from start to finish. A shadowy thinker, it ranks right up there with "Parasite", tackling political, personal and societal themes in the guise of a simple story, in what is now a considerable Bong cannon, and is a much welcome discovery.

Following his international success with Parasite, director Bong Joon-Ho's second feature is re-released in post-lockdown cinemas that's starving for content. Had I seen this back in 2003 when it was first released, I would've concluded that this film, based on the true story of a serial rapist-murderer in a rural Korean town in 1986, ticks so many boxes we associate with Nordic noirs, we could've called it Kimchi noir. Rice paddy fields replace snow-covered landscapes as the menacing backdrop where a mismatched cop duo, one temperamental and prone to bend rules to get results and the other more subdued and contemplative, investigate a series of gruesomely portrayed murders which always take place on sad rainy days. It is a beautifully shot crime drama that's ultimately less about the crime and more about the obsessive detectives and how the case affects them. While I'm not sure if one can track any early signs of greatness here that point to Bong's eventual breakthrough as a future Oscar winner, there is no doubt a strong sense of composition and visual flair at work here, especially in his framing and use of close-ups; while a dark sense of humour permeates his writing, including a wicked sense of justice which in this film manifests in one of the detective's recurring use of a flying kick against (normally innocent) suspects and the fate of his leg in the final act. Though I was initially irritated by the film's more slapstick comedic tone towards Song Kang-ho's Detective Park's incompetence and dubious judgements, that surprisingly ends up making his character almost understandable, if not redemptive even by the final act. Hindsight is a wonderful thing but there's no denying that this is a solid and promising effort from a young director whose elegant storytelling abilities will take him far.
